reviewText: I'd read the book. I've seen many of Oliver Stone's movies. So it's fair to say I approached this movie with some reservations. Unfortunately, it lived down to my every expectation.First the book. The first Winslow book I read wasThe Power of the Dog, which I thought was simply terrific. Based on that book, I've read several of his other works, and in my opinion he hasn't matched the level of that achievement in anything else of his that I've read. I thoughtSavageswas simply okay. A bit too much of the Winslow-patented surfer vibe, and the over-the-hill "dude" stuff for my taste. But when I read that it was being made into a movie, I thought it had some good potential, with the visuals and twisted plot and all.Enter Oliver Stone, a guy with about the most uneven record in Hollywood. When he's hitting his marks, he can make a pretty good flick; "Platoon", "Wall Street". When he's off, his stuff is ridiculous; "JFK" and "W." come immediately to mind.And unfortunately, this is a complete misfire.Stone seems to have taken every opportunity to explore the weaker elements of the book while completely ignoring or perverting its strengths. Some of the performances are completely over the top. I don't know if he was trying for some kind of sarcastic humor approach, or failed satire, or what.Then, to add insult to injury (and why I detracted one star), he gave us the ending that was in the novel.... and then "Oooops! Only kidding!!"... he throws in a SECOND ending, too, that made absolutely no sense at all, and destroyed what little he'd managed to achieve to that point!I mean, what the hell was that all about???I'd have thrown something hard at the screen, but I was watching it on my own plasma big sreen, so that would have been a bit of an overindulgence."Savages"? Do not bother.

reviewText: I will say upfront that I have not read the book that this movie is based on. In fact, I only learned it was based on a book after I watched it. So my review is just about the movie. The movie was entertaining, and I enjoyed watching it, until the ending (I will get to that later, and I will give a SPOILER ALERT before I give anything away). I just am a little bit mystified about what this movie was trying to be. I should also mention that I am a philosophy student, and I tend to interpret everything from that standpoint. I am always looking for the philosophy in everything. If you are uninterested in that kind of thing, I would recommend skipping my review. If you are interested in that kind of thing, well then, buckle up, because you are in for the ride of your life! (did I oversell it?)Other people have already described the plot, so I am just going to jump right into the thematic material. This movie seems to me to have a lot of material for a good movie, I am just not sure it makes that material into anything. There is the title for example. "Savages". The movie revolves around a conflict between relatively peace loving pot growers from California, and a violent Mexican drug cartel, and at various points in the movie each side refers to the other as "savages". Clearly the filmmakers are attempting to make a point here, I am just not sure what it is. That we are all savages at heart? That terms like "civilized", "cultured", and "savage" are relative? These are interesting ideas, and the exploration of those questions would make for a good movie, but as far as I can tell, this movie does not even attempt to explore those questions in any meaningful way. Which does not make it a bad movie, it just leaves me a bit perplexed.The tale is pretty straight forward. The pot growers are relatively decent human beings, and the Mexican cartel comes in and threatens to torture and kill someone they love, and so they retaliate. In other words, a plot you have seen many times before, which does not make it bad, I tend to enjoy good formulaic plots, but I feel like the title of the movie, and the throw away comments about "savages", sets up a kind of expectation that never really gets fulfilled. There is the expectation that something is going to be said on the theme of "savagery", and I just do not think that the film delivers. It would be like an announcement in the paper "Lecture on Savages" by Oliver Stone, Wednesday 7pm-8pm. Then you get there and he does not show up.The closest the film gets to saying anything explicit about "savagery" is at the end of the movie, during the last voiceover, where O. literally reads the dictionary definition of "savage". Um, really? That is where the movie went for its profound insight into savagery? Webster's? Like I said, none of this makes this a bad movie. It is not necessary for movies to provide deep insights into concepts like "savagery" to be good, but if you are hoping for some insight into the concept of "savagery" that you could not get from breaking out the dictionary, I think you will be disappointed with this movie.I think the best scene in the movie is the dinner with Elena (Selma Hayek) and O. (Blake Lively). That seems to me to be one scene where people claim to see some moral complexity in the film, because we get a little peek into the motivations behind Elena's assumption of the throne, and something rare happens: we feel sorry for the head of a drug cartel, even when she seems to be entirely in control, and at the height of her power. That is not entirely true since she is being driven out of Mexico by rival cartels, but we do get a peek into the violence and death that come along with her particular job. It is not an enviable life, and it is a mystery to me why any human being on earth would ever have ambition to become the head of a drug cartel. This, I think, is one of the achievements of the film. I cannot think of any other movie that portrays the head of a drug cartel in that way. Usually those kinds of villains are just caricatures. On the one hand, they represent our own desires for wealth, power, women, or to be free from moral constraints, etc., and on the other, they are empty place holders for all of our hate and fear, so that at the end of the movie, when they get their comeuppance, we all leave the theater feeling like we have experienced some kind of catharsis. All the terror we feel in our everyday lives has been turned back on the people who are responsible for that terror. And it feels good, for a little while anyways. That is the role that heads of drug cartels usually play in movies. This movie deserves credit for "complexifying" the picture a bit (that's right, I just made up a word, I warned you things might get crazy).One of the achievements of this movie is that it actually makes the audience sympathetic with the vicious head of a drug cartel who is holding an innocent woman captive. The problem is, again, I am not really sure what the point is. What is the film trying to say? That the heads of drug cartels are really sad, lonely, and misunderstood? I also do not think that this is really "moral complexity". It is "character complexity". The makers of the film created an interesting character, and they deserve credit, but there is no moral complexity there. Her actions are heinous. We do not leave the cinema with any deep questions about what is right or wrong.The same can be said in relation to the pot growers. Their dilemma does not really raise any deep moral questions. They are just in a bad situation, but that is what movies do. They put people in bad situations. My review is sort of  turning into a response to some other reviews I read, which is not what I intended. I just do not agree with the claim that this movie explores "moral complexity" any more deeply than any other movie that puts characters in situations where they have to make difficult decisions. Movies set these kinds of dilemmas up all the time, not because they are exploring moral themes, but because it creates tension. Is the good character going to let the person they love die, or are they going to commit a morally reprehensible act and lose their soul? So I do not think this movie is really saying anything very interesting about morality either.The last theme I will mention is the theme of our modern pot culture. It seems to me that Oliver Stone is taking some shots at that California culture (and I live in California by the way), particularly in the dinner scene, where O. is explaining her decision to leave community college to the person who is holding her captive and threatening to cut off her head if her "boyfriends" do not do as she says. That was, as I said before, a good scene. But I have to ask again, what is the point? What is Oliver Stone saying about our culture? It is possible that he is saying that it has a dark side that people do not pay attention to. That is an interesting idea! And it is the one idea that I think the film really does develop to some degree. There is, on the one hand, the sunny California beaches, and the friendly neighborhood pot stores, and then, there are the dark cells where people have their heads cut off by chain saws. People certainly have a tendency to ignore the dark side of things. Actually, what I should say is, people fail to see that the light and dark sides are often two sides of the same coin. You cannot have one without the other (in some cases, at least). In the case that this movie explores, you cannot have the the pot filled California lifestyle without the dark cells and decapitated bodies. Of course, one could certainly argue that the two sides only go together because marijuana is still illegal, and who knows, perhaps Oliver Stone meant the movie to be a giant "legalize marijuana" commercial.It is possible that I am searching too hard for this movie's "message" since it is, after all, an Oliver Stone picture, and we expect a message when Oliver Stone is involved. I read conflicting reviews of this movie. Some reviewers claimed that it was refreshing to see an Oliver Stone picture without a message, that was just good, not-so-wholesome entertainment. Other reviewers claimed that this movie represents Oliver Stone's triumphant return to the soap box. I am not sure it is a good thing that people are having such conflicting responses. I tend to think the movie is probably trying to say something, I just am not really sure what that is.From what I have said so far, it probably sounds like I really hated the movie, but I actually found it to be compulsively watchable. It works as an "action" movie, with interesting characters, and an interesting plot. I am just not sure that people should be trying to make more out of it than that. There were times when I had some complaints with the writing. A number of lines that seemed like they were meant to be profound fell flat for me. Especially in the voice-overs that open and close the movie. The acting was pretty good for the most part. No surprise that I thought Benicio del Toro, Selma Hayek, and John Travolta were the highlights in that regard. I could watch Benicio del Toro play a sociopath for hours on end.Finally, I have to say something about the ending, so here is my SPOILER ALERT. I am just not sure what to make of the ending. Unlike most movies this movie had two endings, and to be honest, I found them both unsatisfying. The first ending is unsatisfying because all the good guys die, the second is unsatisfying because it is basically a farce and anti-climactic. I have to say, I felt a brief moment of relief when the movie decided to rewind and replay the ending, because I did find the first ending unsatisfying, but it was sort of a slap in the face to be presented with another, almost equally unsatisfying ending, to replace the first. Not only did I find both endings to the movie unsatisfying, but I found the fact that there were two endings in the first place to be unsatisfying, and I cannot, for the life of me, figure out why Stone decided to do that. It does not seem to me to serve any purpose. Neither ending seems to me to be making a point, or serve any artistic purpose. There is a "feel bad" ending where all the good guys die, and a "feel good" ending where everyone lives, and all the good guys move to a tropical island and live happily ever after (that might be an exaggeration). I am someone who firmly believes that art does not exist to fulfill our "human all too human desires". The short stories of Anton Chekhov, for example, are beautiful stories, but they almost always leave the reader unsatisfied. They are also great works of art, and the dissatisfaction felt by the reader is part of the artistic message. So I am fine, in principle, with unsatisfying endings, if they serve some artistic purpose. I just cannot figure out why Stone decided to have not one, but two, unsatisfying endings?It seems to me that you have two choices in regard to ending a movie: you can provide the satisfying ending, or you can decide to send a message with the ending. Since it does not seem to me that this movie was sending any very clear message with the ending, why not accept your status as an "action" flick, and just give the audience the satisfying ending they are craving, where the good guys triumph in a climactic gun battle, Lado (Benicio del Toro), who is the real villain of the film, gets what is coming to him, and everyone lives happily ever after. If you decide not to go either route, if you decide to provide an unsatisfying ending without sending any message, at least have the decency to give us ONE ending instead of TWO.If it were not for the ending, I would not hesitate to recommend this film, as a compellingly watchable film. It does not, in my opinion, deal with deep themes (likeNatural Born KillersorPlatoon (Special Edition)), but it is a good, entertaining, watchable movie. With the ending I am not sure what to recommend. Why can't you people just make up your own minds? Why does everything always have to be my fault?

Stone and 2 other writer cooked up this rambling script (overlong at 2 hr 11 mins .  90 mins maybe more desirable but the film makers will not have so many things throw at you) seemingly had a good time and possibly under the influence as well while writing and directing the film(watch out for the shot of Stone dancing in the clouds with Lively).  Unfortunately this viewer did not share their enthusiasm.  The main problems are the weak and unfocused story/screenplay, superficial characterizations and some bad casting(Selma Hayek) and unusual but unsatisfactory ending.  Of the 3 main characters, Taylor Kitsch was supposed to be the veteran war killing machine but with the exception of his first sex scene, his rage seemed to disappear altogether right afterwards.  Blake Lively worked hard and might be the only female actor who kept her top on during violent sex.  Only Aaron Johnson managed to give a sensitive and intense performance throughout.  I believe it was his acting chops, rather than the script or direction. Credits must be given to John Travolta and Benicio Del Toro for giving us a couple of brilliant scenes together.2 stars for the movie.  1 star for Travolta and Del Toro.

reviewText: This isn't the first movie to come out this year to use this sort of narration, is it? Maybe "Fallen" is just coming to mind and that weak effort that left a sour taste in everyone's mouth reared its ugly head right from the start. But the familiarity slowly begins to wear off once O reveals her two lovers and what they do for a living. Speaking as someone who isn't really a fan of anything Oliver Stone has done, hopes weren't very high for "Savages," but the trailers were at least intriguing. What you end up with is one of Stone's best efforts that is nearly tarnished thanks to a really feeble conclusion.The cast for this is ridiculous. Out of the three movies Taylor Kitsch has done this year, this is easily the best. He seems more focused as Chon and the character is more brutal than John Carter or Lieutenant Alex Hopper. Aaron Johnson is a bit more laid back. His best scene is when Ben kills for the first time and he completely freaks out afterward. Blake Lively doesn't really do anything different compared to what she did in "The Town" other than bang two guys on screen.Benicio Del Toro and John Travolta don't really step outside their boundaries either, but the characters they portray are ones they do so well that you won't really mind. Del Toro is just outstanding and both characters are entertaining in this sleazy kind of way. Salma Hayek is the one people are talking about the most though. It seems like there's already early Oscar buzz around her role. Elena is emotional, compelling, and intimidating; three things all great and memorable movie villains should be.The soundtrack is literally all over the place, as well. It feels like it covers nearly every genre out there from 8-bit beats to industrial sounds, a full orchestra to dance music, hip hop tracks with Spanish vocals to piano, horns, and various different types of guitars. It's so different from everything else you've heard this year that it's difficult not to remember it."Savages" is ridiculously good for about three-fourths of its duration; like borderline the top score of whatever you rate movies kind of good. The last twenty minutes or so completely ruins whatever it had going for it though. It's like "Breaking Bad" with pot instead of meth nearly the entire time. How do you screw that up? A really stupid ending practically destroys the whole deal.It's like everything was progressing smoothly during the production process and then when it came down to the ending, Oliver Stone just ran in the room, pushed everyone behind him, and said, "Step back, I'll take it from here, ladies and gents." Then he proceeded to take this huge, drug-induced crap all over the finale and the smell nearly ruins the rest of the picture.It is just massively frustrating. There's this brilliant cast, some pretty intense torture scenes, tons of blood, this fantastic soundtrack, explosive action, and even this amazing scene in a car between Aaron Johnson, Taylor Kitsch, and John Travolta that's reminiscent of that infamous car scene in "Pulp Fiction" where Vincent Vega's gun accidentally goes off. But then the ending comes along and once the credits roll, you're just left with the overpowering urge to kick a cluster of helpless, unsuspecting baby seals to the moon.

reviewText: Chon and Ben grow the best pot in America.  Actually, it's Afghani pot, smuggled in by Chon when he returns from active duty.  O, named for Ophelia from Shakespeare's Hamlet, is the girl both guys love, and she loves them both equally.  Whereas Chon brings the brute strength and security, Ben offers gentleness and stability.  They've got themselves a perfect world...until the Mexican cartels take notice and kidnap O for the smallest slight.  Now Chon and Ben have to get her back, and they're about to descend in a world of violence born in the heat of Mexico's drug violence.SAVAGES isn't a terrible film; don't read the 3 stars and think, "Wow, he hates this movie."  If I hated it, I'd give it one star, maybe two if there were some genuinely awesome moments.  SAVAGES is a decent film with some great elements, mainly the supporting cast: Benicio del Torro and Salma Hayek play three-dimensional villains, while John Travolta turns in a smarmy, enjoyable performance as a corrupt DEA agent (he's always at his best when he sinks his fangs into a villainous role).  Look too for a cameo from Shea Whigham; it makes you wish he was in the movie more.The major problems with SAVAGES lie with the script and the directing.  The former offers the three leads little to do.  Taylor Kitsch (JOHN CARTER), Aaron Johnson (KICK ASS), and Blake Lively (THE TOWN) are all capable of delivering better performances than this.  It's just, their characters--lifted from Don Winslow's novel--are utterly two-dimensional.  One scene in particular could've let Kitsch show his range--but instead of being as powerful and effective as writers Winslow, Stone, and Shane Salerno intended, it comes off as flat and emotionless.That brings us to the direction.  Oliver Stone has given us some great films, both as a writer (SCARFACE) and director (WALL STREET).  Now, SAVAGES is arguably the best full movie he's made since 1999's ANY GIVEN SUNDAY; I say full because the first 2/3 of WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS were quite good (but the final third was so awful that people tend to forget that fact).  But saying SAVAGES is his best recent effort isn't saying much, considering what we're comparing it to.  Occasionally, Stone presents us with glimmers of his old self, but overall the direction is surprisingly lazy, considering this is the man who gave us the frenetically-feverish NATURAL BORN KILLERS.  It's almost as though Stone is trying to marry that film with the weirdness of his later U TURN, but the marriage is a fitful one.  Ultimately, SAVAGES doesn't come off quite as good as it could have.  It's entertaining, mostly, though the script doesn't try hard to keep your attention, and you really don't care about the fate of the three main characters.  It's a decent popcorn flick, but we expect more from Stone--though, given his recent track record, maybe we shouldn't.

reviewText: We are all savages, no matter how we attempt to disguise it. Oliver Stone has brought some brilliant films to the screen - Platoon, Wall Street, Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, Born on the Fourth of July, Natural Born Killers, Nixon, W., Heaven and Earth, World Trade Center, etc - and it is with the expectation that his current film will live up to those standards that most viewers commit to the 147 minutes of SAVAGES. The film is long on gore and drugs, delivers some rather caricatures of ideas (Benicio Del Toro, Selma Hayak, John Travolta) and waste a lot of time on inconsequential things.  But the story itself has some merit, though it has been done many times before: the drug market can turn people into savages.Entrepreneurs Ben (Aaron Johnson), a peaceful and charitable marijuana producer, and friend Chon (Taylor Kitsch), a macho, hunky, rough former Navy SEAL, run a lucrative, homegrown industry - raising some of the best weed ever developed. They also share a one-of-a-kind love with Ophelia (Blake Lively) in a three-way romance. Life is an idyllic triad in their Southern California town of Laguna Beach ... until the Mexican Baja Cartel decides to move in and demands that the trio partners with them. When the merciless head of the BC, Elena (Salma Hayek) and her enforcer, Lado (Benicio Del Toro), underestimate the unbreakable bond of the three friends, Ben and Chon - with the reluctant assistance of a dirty DEA agent (John Travolta) in cahoots with El Azul (Joaquín Cosio) - wage a seemingly unwinnable war against the cartel. And so begins a series of increasingly vicious ploys and maneuvers in a high stakes, savage battle of wills involving the kidnapping of Ophelia as well as the kidnapping of Elena's daughter. Throw in cameos by Emile Hirsch, Demián Bichir, and what seems to be a cast of thousands, top it off by a cutesy ending suggested by the opening lines of the film, and try to get past the boring voice over storytelling by Blake lively and settle in to the gore of beheadings, and other gruesome events and you have Oliver Stone's latest. The film as its moments but it goes on far too long and doesn't have the class of the original novel by Don Winslow (who surprisingly shows up as a screenwriter!). For those who love gore and some fine actors doing a turn for the money, join in.  Grady Harp, November 12

reviewText: Oliver Stone's Savages had an awesome trailer... that was probably the best aspect of the movie, the movie itself was a pretty bland revenge story that was shot beautifully, for a guns-blazing type of story though Oliver Stone sure made it drag, I felt like I was sitting in the theater for 4 hours watching this, similar to when I watched Natural Born Killers that dragged on like a carcass as well.The characters were really standard, we have California girl, ex-marine hardass, and stoner-genius Buddhist, all as a threeway couple that only exists in Oliver Stone's mind. Hell the Mexican gang members had more character to them, Salma Hayek balancing being a drug lord and a single mother and Benicio Del Toro being a sadistic henchman with higher aspirations, while John Travolta is hammy as always as a corrupt FBI agent. The stoner-genius' employees all seemed like they belonged in a Mac commercial and really didn't serve much purpose to the overall movie, stoner-genius could've just said "I've got our tracks covered", and BAM! 20 minutes cut down.The saving grace of Savage's characters however is that they're all played incredibally well, the actors breathe life into these stale hollow stereotypes and make them empathetic real people, really impressive on the actors parts, especially the guy who played stoner-genius and Salma Hayek. O herself seemed more like a fantasy character to get this whole story in motion but she was O-k (didja gettit??). Benecio Del Toro was wonderful, and I never thought I'd care to see him and John Travolta in the same room, but the scene where they were together was wonderful, they played off each other like a game of tennis. If you're a Benecio fan another movie similar-ish to this that I'd recommend is Way of the Gun, another hostage taken over the border thing.Savages had a really nice style to it though which I'm sure you can tell just by that cover, it captured Southern California and Mexico perfectly and the main characters I could easily see living there.The Story was really, REALLY, basic, a California girl gets kidnapped and her two boyfriends (only in Oliver Stone's fantasy) will do whatever it takes to get her back from the Mexican Cartel or whoever that kidnapped her. There's about 30 minutes well establishing who the characters are and how they live their good lives, the calm before the storm I guess, then after the girl gets kidnapped the guys go over for a bit what to do and how to do it, and eventually they decide to attack one of their deals and pin it on one of their own men, problem with that is this whole part takes about an hour. For the most part we see the Cartel trying to figure out what happened, *snooze*.Then when we finally get to the ending scene they do a standard hostage tradeoff that goes in opposite directions for no apparent reason. At first we see the guys shoot all the Mexicans, then the stoner-genius gets shot in the throat and the marine and the girl basically commit suicide so they can die with him, then suddenly we hear "but that's how I wish it'd go down" and suddenly we see them back at the same deal 2 minutes ago and a helicoptor pops out and arrests Salma Hayek while everyone else gets away scott-free, WHAT?!??! Not only does Oliver Stone give us a false ending for NO REASON, he goes with the most cliche happy ending that completely contradicts the trailer/opening of the movie where the girl says "I'm not alive by the end of this", yeah bulls***. Also why did she want everyone to die? It's like Oliver Stone used the last couple of pages of the script to wipe his ass then threw it at the production company and told them to interpret that into the story.Also an interesting aspect in the story that was just dropped which was when the Cartel saw the weakness in stoner-genius and made him finish killing someone they tortured, meanwhile O is watching on a security camera. They could've gone many ways with this, O getting Stockholm's Syndrome because she sees what horrible things her lover did, the guys turning 'savage' on the Cartel and executing Salma Hayek's daughter after getting O back, so much damn potential and they pretty much just forget about that part and we see the three of them holding hands and smiling in Indonesia or something, blech.My main problem with Savages is that almost nothing happens story-wise, it's so straightforward, the Cartel kidnaps someone the guys love, so they kidnap someone the head-honcho loves and they tradeoff, all that other stuff going on in the story just felt like filler because it doesn't change anyone's course of action throughout the dragging 2 hours, leaving the whole experience feeling rather vapid and pointless. I didn't read the book so I don't know how it plays out there but simply from a movie standpoint the story could've used a few rewrites and an editor. The whole reason Savages exists is cinematic catharsis for gringos who are frustrated with all the horrendous acts going on right across the border, and little more.

reviewText: Director Oliver Stone ("W.") brings us an R-rated violent, bloody, repugnant visualization of the contemporary drug business in California and Mexico. We already know the death toll approaches 50,000 for the last six years. (Why do Americans keep buying drugs and by so doing, contribute to the deaths of Mexicans, most of whom are innocent?) An unlikely but inseparable trio of "peaceful, California pot growers" go up against a Mexican drug cartel.We see:* Taylor Kitsch ("John Carter") is Chon, Special-Ops trained but derailed by the two people he loves.* Blake Lively ("Gossip Girl"), a California blonde, is O, a delectable dimwit who loves BOTH of the guys in their little ménage à trois. When taken hostage, her chronic drug use backfires on her.* Aaron Johnson ("Albert Nobbs") is Ben, the soulful botanist who has developed a highly marketable variety of marijuana.* John Travolta ("From Paris With Love"), sporting one face-lift too many, is Dennis, the go-to guy in the government, who plays all sides against the middle.* Benicio del Toro ("The Wolfman") is Lado, an hombre with slippery loyalties. His character seems to take pleasure in devising creative ways to torture and kill.* Salma Hayak ("Grown Ups") is Elena, the jefa of a major cartel. She has political, economic and geographic concerns but remains in charge.* Emile Hirsch ("Milk") is Spin, the tech whiz who can create a paper trail that will lead the best tracker astray.Man's inhumanity to man is singularly repellent to me. Even though I tried to avoid looking at the screen, I came out with enough chaotic images of drug use, sexual encounters, beheadings, whippings, tortures, gunfire and blowie uppie stuff to last me a lifetime. I don't know, and I don't want to know, these methods, so I recoil from the images.Near the conclusion, Stone pulled a cinematic trick that triggered a collective groan from our screening audience. As we exited the theater, we realized that none of us knew exactly how it ended...nor did we care...The DVD from Amazon.com will prove my point.

reviewText: Now, there's two ways to look at violence in movies. You can wave it off and pretend it doesn't influence anything or you can say that it surely plays a role in today's craziness in our society.  There are so many troubled people out there, how can you really make yourself believe that the violence you see in Hollywood doesn't contribute to put crazy ideas in their heads? Especially when the characters using that violence are so jaded about it? It has to have at least a minimum impact. This Oliver Stone movie, this "Savages" , is well done, with great actors, great cinematography, great editing and music. The rhythm is hypnotizing and you really want to know how the heck it's going to end. But I had trouble with the violence. And the way it was portrayed. Maybe I'm getting old. I still love action, though. But when you see all the real shootings happening out there and all the sadness caused by the real weapons and the psychos using them, it sure makes you wonder about the righteousness of Oliver Stone's goal here.  Do we really need to be reminded how savage we can be? Right now? In 2013? A lot of people are complaining (rightly so, I think) about the role of Hollywood in today's culture of weapons. Even though just about every character in it was despicable or, at least, morally... um, challenged, and I wasn't able to root for any of them.Worth seeing, however, are Travolta and  del Toro.  And not, really, for the good acting they do.  Travolta must have been paid extra to appear in the film as he did:  overweight and balding.  And del Toro?  Chubby, bloated and, very oddly, looking  much like Brad Pitt with eight hours of make-up.I will mention one group, however, that I'm sure loved "Savages."  And that would be the Coastal Orange County Chamber of Commerce (if there is such a thing).  Laguna Beach looked like paradise, and even the nearby shopping malls looked liked great places to go.  So, kudos to the cinematographer.  Because I used to live there, and none of that was ever as appealing in reality as it looked in "Savages."  If only they had done as good a job with the rest of the film.

The directing by Oliver Stone (who also co-wrote the screenplay) is great. The screenplay (based on Don Winslow's novel) by Winslow, Stone & Shane Salerno (who also executive produced) is great.The music by Adam Peters is great. The cinematography by Dan Mindel is great. reviewText: Savagesis a film about two successful Laguna Beach, CA marijuana dealers that are amongst the top of the business. In addition, they are friends from High School. Ben, played by Aaron Johnston, is a Buddhist, incredibly giving, and the more gentle of the best friends. Chon, played by Taylor Kitsch, is the more outspoken and hard-nosed of the two, amplified by his background in the war as a Navy Seal.  Both best friends/dealers share one girlfriend, O (Blake Lively), who ends up playing a pivotal role in the plot. O, in addition, serves as the narrator throughout the 130 minute film.Things grow awry for the Laguna Beach boys when the Mexican drug cartel wants to be a part of  their lucrative business. The cartel assert their corrupt power and authority by holding O hostage until Ben and Chon meet their demands. O is the most important facet of either of Ben or Chon's life, so they know they must devise means to save their beloved. Using both Elena (Salma Hayek), the top of the cartel, and her no. 2 Lado's (Benicio Del Toro) thinking against them with the help of a corrupt DEA Agent (John Travolta), Ben and Chon end up rescuing their mutual gal-pal.The film was one I highly anticipated seeing, but failed to grace my hometown.  After viewing, it was not a film I would envision Oliver Stone directing, but I was pleasantly surprised as the film was better than I expected it to be.  The film is 'savage' itself in many ways, give prominence of sexual situations, substance use, and violence/gore. Perhaps it is the plot and some of the plot's savagery that leaves some room for criticism, particularly given some of the mixed reviews on amazon.com in particular.  It is not a crime film for the faint of heart as the graphic nature will turn off many. Quibbles and nitpicking aside, all-in-all,Savagesis worth watching and I would gladly view it more than once.

reviewText: Oliver Stone returns to his most violent movie since "Natural Born Killer," this time focusing on a couple marijuana entrepreneurs and their shared girlfriend. His lifelong friend Ben (Aaron Johnson) is hooked on Buddhism and doing charitable work in Africa.  His college degree is in business and botany.  How perfect. reviewText: The first thing Savages does is to pull a punch: in a sweaty basement imprisoned Mexican workers are captured on home video suffering atrocities, off screen, at the hands of a chainsaw-wielding sadist. It's meant to be a bracer, but it doesn't quite shock because it only implies, and is followed too quickly by opening credits scrolling prettily over Southern California sun and sand, beautiful people frolicking in rolling, reverb-drenched surf guitars.An odd dissonance: an opening which doesn't know whether to be Arthur or Martha. It's kind of a theme.Over stylish fast-cut editing we meet our narrator, a girl called O (Blake Lively). O (for Ophelia, which we're helpfully informed is from Hamlet) is the fulcrum of the film, and she introduces dual heroes Ben and Chon, both of whom are her boyfriend. Dual heroes. They're good drug dealers. We meet some bad ones soon enough: the dudes with the chainsaw.Amongst our dual heroes we have a sensitive one, Ben (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and a hard bastard, Chon (Taylor Kitsch). They are a Cheech & Chong for the net generation: they're even name-checked that way. Only they're not as funny. They share O: it's a yin and yang thing. A Bizarre love triangle, then? Some submerged fear and loathing between the beaux? Underplayed. Implausibly underplayed. Thus the whole three-way relationship, which you would think would ooze of it, seems contrived.In any case, why have two heroes, if not to harvest the drama that flows from the submerged resentment between them? It is as if Oliver Stone can't make up his mind: it speaks to a muddle-headedness with which the picture is shot through. For now, though, no matter: early exchanges are slick, voguish and handsome, being not troubled much by way of plot exposition.Things start to fall apart when Stone moves onto that job. To do so he dials back the modish editing, but without that distraction, a preposterous screenplay reveals itself. The vibe is confused: my best guess is that Stone is shooting for Quentin Tarantino's blend of irony and brutality, but Savages isn't nearly cool enough to carry it off. For one thing, Stone doesn't trust us to be hip to his references, so explains: "IED - that means improvised explosive device". (We are told this particular fact twice.) Perhaps this is meant for viewers who are thinking of the contraceptive coil.Now a Roberto Rodriguez or a Quentin Tarantino would never patronise his audience in that way - he would expect you to keep up: no concessions for laggards; and when he sought ironic belly laughs he would therefore get them. In Savages, the theatre's laughter, which grew bolder as the picture wore on, was not ironic. It was embarrassed: Did someone really ask Benicio Del Toro to say that? And he did?Del Toro, then: The more we see of him and his cohort of Mexican provocateurs, the less menacing they are. Del Toro's accent is direct from Ren & Stimpy.  He wears a ridiculous wig. Despite doing despicable and ultraviolent things he seems content to play for laughs.His boss, also in a ridiculous wig, is Salma Hayek. She is a drug lord. Salma Hayek a drug lord? Good lord. Poor Hayek is way out of her depth, hobbled by an atrocious script and required to play a character riven with so many contradictions it is a wonder she doesn't spontaneously implode: by the end of the picture, fairly much, she has done. In the mean time, characters labour over exposition, frequently telegraphing it to each other - literally - over skype. But then, for daggers-drawn blood rivals, they also spend more time than I would visiting each other boldily. Especially since they're meant to be in different countries.In fairness, Stone keeps the pace up and the picture is never less than entertaining. John Travolta has a whale of a time as a bent DEA agent playing every angle, but this is not his Pulp Fiction of the 2010s.Fundamentally, the flimsy superstructure of Stone's enterprise has no chance of supporting the colossal weight of ludicrousness that Don Winslow's premise hoists upon it.  By the time we get to the most equivocal ending I can remember - yet again, Stone seems to want to have a bob each way, as if the focus group screening came out split 50/50, so he puts both endings in - the whole edifice is strewn across the landscape, a blast radius wider than one of Chon's IEDs*.*That's "improvised explosive devices" in case you were wondering.Olly Buxton
summary: Cheech & Chong go crazy-ape bonkers in Southern California

reviewText: This is a film for the middle class US audience who need a perspective on drug manufacture and distribution different from the Miami Vice take. The main characters, two US cannabis entrepreneurs, embody a group of young people with an ethic that is far more interesting than the the usual action film depiction of the greedy executive on the 86th floor of an urban skyrise.  Their dualist moralities are a metaphor for the spirituality seeking/relief from emotional anguish duality that drives the consumption of mind altering substances in this country (the US).  The narrator is their lover, a very appealing, educated, and lost young woman. The cast and acting are excellent, the sex, the best I have seen in awhile, the politics- right on. Hayak, Benicio, and Travolta are excellent in their roles, highlighting some touches of humanity and family values, with a large dose of monstrosity on the part del Toro that is all too reminiscent of what we suspect goes on at in increasing gallop in the world.

reviewText: Murder, marijuana trafficking, bloody shootings, sadistic torture, point-blank executions, gratuitous graphic sex and enough sleaze to fill a pig trough are the hallmarks of Oliver Stone's "Savages." The last dud that Oliver Stone turned out was the sequel to "Wall Street."  Inert as that was, and it was almost embarrassingly bad, this go-round is truly awful, filled with gratuitous violence, torture, sex, a mediocre script and a ridiculous story line. This film reeks of sleaze and body odor.  Once upon a time there were a pair of sleazy, grungy, tattooed, sweaty, distinctly unappetizing guys (Taylor Kitsch (aptly named) as "Chon," and Aaron Taylor-Johnson as "Ben"), who lived in a gorgeous beach house in Southern California with their blonde paramour ("O" played by Blake Lively), while cultivating marijuana in a gigantic state-of-the-art warehouse under optimal conditions, such that THEIR marijuana was thirty percent stronger than Mexican pot.  Yeah, right.  Along came a mean old Mexican drug cartel, with Benecio Del Toro as their vicious henchman, trying to co-opt them and muscle in on their business.  When they wouldn't capitulate, the meanies kidnapped their sweetie.  What follows is two hours of seedy violence, complete with Skyping back and forth between the "good" guys and the cartel, including scenes of brutal torture and endless grunge. It's about as lowlife as you can imagine, with a bad script, mediocre acting by the leads, and Salma Hayek as a nasty drug overlord bossing the Del Toro character around.  The plot is like Swiss cheese it has so many holes in it.  I wonder if Mr. Stone has children, and I wonder if he has ever given thought to the fact that producing violent garbage like this only contributes to more shootings and violence in the real world.  It's also very disturbing that Universal Studios would release a film that is so morally debased and reprehensible.  Equally surprising is the presence of John Travolta, who stumbles through his role as a government agent playing both sides of the street, and Benecio Del Toro, who can't possibly be so desperate that he would stoop to portraying this kind of garbage. After subjecting yourself to this movie, you feel an immediate urger to shower, so you can wash all the filth off.  God help the film industry.
summary: Sleazy, filthy, lowlife, violent, pornographic trash

reviewText: If you never read the book, this movie might be alright.  Like maybe 3 stars.If you DID read the book, you'll probably think even less of it.  And I know that's common.  Fans of books often hate adaptations.  But this one is especially egregious.But I'm not reviewing this as an adaptation.  I'm just reviewing it as a film.  And as a film it's pretty dull, the acting is not good from the leads, it's ultimately forgettable, but it really LOOKS great and is filmed well.  So I guess that's something.Oliver Stone used to be a great story teller.  Or maybe he just got lucky a few times.  Platoon is great.  JFK is entertaining--though insane.  I love Wall Street.  I even kind of like The Doors.  Most everything else ranges from "awful" (Alexander) to "interesting mess" (Wall Street 2, Natural Born Killers, W., Any Given Sunday, etc).  I think Savages falls in that second group.  But maybe I'm being kind.First off, the casting is stupid.  The best performances come from Del Toro and Hayek--who only have supporting rolls.  The leads are awful.  Lively is like a wooden Paltrow.  I like Friday Night Lights, but unless Taylor Kitsch is talking about Texas football and drinking beer, he generally comes off about as convincing as a cigar store statue.  Aaron Taylor is just not good.And then there's a tone.  "Show, don't tell" is what good story tellers are supposed to do.  Apparently Stone isn't interested in that.  So he gives us a narrator, a ton of exposition, and even a "twist" ending that's stupid.Those willing to forgive Stone for the plot may think he's held to the source material.  But that's not really the case.  In the book, the storytelling is light and breezy.  Stone goes for heavy-handed and sentimental.  In the book, O. is a vapid material girl.  Here, she's just a whiny captive.  Chon is as 2 dimensional as characters get.  And Ben is some generic movie hippie from central casting.  Everything about this movie takes a book that is light and cool and fast-paced and turns it into some kind of melodrama with action...and if I wanted to see that, I'd plant myself on the couch and labor through Michael Mann's "Heat" for 7 hours...because at least it's entertaining.

reviewText: Checked it out from the library and have tried to watch it twice all the way through, but could not stomach it.  The torture scenes are highly distressing, so I've decided to skip through them on my next attempt to view the movie - they seem very realistic to me.  Didn't understand the relationship between the leads, understood that they liked each other, but not why, didn't get enough information about them; they are all beautiful, but didn't understand them.  The drug business was presented in a terrifying way, and I didn't understand why the leads were in it; apparently they had been discussing quitting before the hostile takeover attempt by the more violent competitor, the story shows the two owners disagreeing about the timing to quit the business, but the kidnap of O happened all too quickly for them to get out at their own pace.  Money seemed to be the reason everyone was involved in the business, from the leads, to their competitors, to the crooked DEA agent - no one seemed that concerned about breaking the law, which I guess makes sense if a character is in the business.  Drug films distress me because they seem to concentrate the ugliest aspects of human nature into a 90 minute production, which is hard to take, so I think I'm already biased against them, which is why I gave the film an extra half star, to counter-weigh my bias.  The actors were good, the competitors were frighteningly violent, and the leads, in kidnapping the competitors child, showed that they have similar business tactics as their competitor when push comes to shove.  I did not know why I should sympathize with the leads, they are criminals knowingly working in a violent, illegal business; instead of getting out when they were pressured by their competitors, they dug in their heels - I don't care why they dug in their heels, they were stupid to remain in such a high risk, violent, illegal, venture.  Hard to sympathize with stupidity.  I found it believable that the competitor, a woman, had her business stolen from her by her lieutenants.  Story doesn't really give new information about the drug business, just another take on it from the point of view of the sex/love interest of one of the players.  I'll attempt to watch it again, but as I couldn't understand the leads' relationship, and I find the violent drug business terrifying, I think this is just not a story to my taste. 2 and a half stars for eye candy provided by the leads, their locales, and for the filmmakers efforts.

That said, there is little use of your surround system being used for discreet channeling of fx.  Even panning from the many vehicles across or past the viewer is very limited.  I don't know if there is a difference (other than the extended version  being blocked from view) between rental Blu Rays and store bought Blu Rays, but if appears to me that little effort went into the audio editing when it comes to utilizing your complete audio surround system.  This film could have had plenty of it and did not.  Despite this, the audio leveling seemed appropriate and I did not have any difficulty hearing dialogue over the soundtrack.  Set my volume levels once and didn't need to go back to it.Certainly, this is not a Blu Ray film you would want to use as a DEMO disc to show off your system with, however, the video transfer is just fine and the audio is nicely uncompressed, just no discreet work for the foleys.All my movie reviews are of this nature and focus only on the quality of the transfer to BluRay so check them and see if they are of help as well.Hopefully, this review has been of some help to you in determining your purchase, hope I am on the correct path with a review of the transfer quality as opposed to providing plot summaries.Thanks

reviewText: Can two men share a woman and stay friends? Can a small, independent group of marijuana dealers take on a Mexican cartel? Has Oliver Stone lost his touch?We are given a brief history of two of the lead characters, Ben and Chon (played by Aaron Johnson and Taylor Kitsch) by their girlfriend and the film's narrator O (short for Ophelia, played by Blake Lively). Ben (Johnson) is a college graduate who majored in business and botany. Chon (Kitsch) is a veteran who returned from Afghanistan with the seeds that became an extremely potent form of marijuana and the foundation of their successful business. Ben contributes a great deal of his income to worthy causes and travels extensively. While he's away, O and Chon receive a video containing numerous severed heads and chainsaw. They fear Ben has been killed until he returns home a short time later. They had a scheduled meeting with the cartel and so, they go ahead with it. The cartel representatives propose that Ben and Chon join their organization, but rather than consider their offer, they say they take the time they've been given to consider it and make plans to flee the country. A DEA agent named Dennis (played by John Travolta) tells them that the partnership is the best option. They disagree but, before they can leave the country, O is kidnapped. Ben and Chon hear this directly from Elena Sanchez, the leader of the cartel who ordered it. Elena (played by Salma Hayek) tells the two men that she intends to hold O hostage until they honor the terms of their agreement. During that time, she's held prisoner amid miserable surroundings and guarded by a cartel henchman who goes by Lado (played by Benicio del Toro).Now, regardless of what anyone might say about its historical accuracy, or lack thereof, I greatly enjoyed JFK. Same goes for Wall Street, Nixon, The Doors and Born on the Fourth of July. I thought Any Given Sunday was alright, but nowhere near as good as the others I've mentioned. I don't know if this movie's failure is something to be blamed on Stone, the actors or the source material, but the story didn't really go anywhere and the characters were completely unrealistic. I'm not saying I won't watch it again, but I certainly won't pay for the opportunity.

reviewText: Two best friends Chon (Taylor Kitsch), who is an Iraq and Afghanistan war veteran, and Ben (Aaron Johnson), who has a Berkeley degree in business and botany, make a lot of money growing high-quality marijuana in California. As in an old George Roy Hill movie, they are living a carefree lifestyle, both sleeping with the same woman known as "O" (Blake Lively), until a Mexican drug cartel led by Elena (Salma Hayek) moves in. Things get out of control. Body count mounts."Savages" is one of those films that could have been shorter and better. This is supposed to be a darkly entertaining crime drama, and what you need in making one is good storytelling and interesting characters. You don't need flashy camerawork. You don't need Blake Lively's bland voiceover that goes on and on. The character of "O" and her back story is the least interesting part of the film.Chon and Ben are marginally better (at least they have something to do in the story), but the film is easily stolen by Benicio del Toro's bravura performance as the killer. John Travolta is a DEA agent Dennis. Emile Hirsch is a computer hacker. Both actors (especially Hirsch) are so underused.I simply don't know why Oliver Stone wanted to make this movie, which is neither thrilling nor funny enough. As for the ending that is far from satisfactory, it looks as if director just doesn't know what to do with it. Don't expect much from "Savages." It is not a terrible movie. It is not great, either.

reviewText: Within the first five minutes, I wanted to turn this movie off--as soon as she said in the voice over, the eyeroll-worthy "wargasms", I had had enough.  I have very little patience for movies lately.Even so, I forced myself to continue watching--it's Oliver Stone, right?Oh, but it gets worse, because "O" then watches a video of decapitated heads and has no human reaction.  "Oh, like people being tortured and beheaded, like. um, sigh and stuff"  And whilst the "men" then discuss this dangerous new development--another drug cartel wishing to take them over with threats of death included, the dingbat girlfriend joins the conversation and all but twirls her hair and bats her eyes and says, "Let's, like, go party and stuff!"  I paraphrase, forgive me.Is she concerned with this seething, vicious threat to herself, her way of living, or to these two men that she supposedly loves SO much?  No!  Gee, I would be.  But, you know, that's just me.They plan to leave the country, escape the cartel, and what does she do next?  She goes to the mall!!!!!  And the morons LET her!!  Because, you know, when attempting to double cross a clever drug cartel, I always plan on calmly, dreamily promenading through department stores, making innumerable purchases, and changing into new clothes--WHILE I'M SHOPPING.IN THE REAL WORLD,  I'd be freaking out, terrified that something bad would happen, I'd leave immediately--Stone could have milked that part of the film, he could have really saturated it with such incredible suspense and genuine fear, it could have been so gripping.  But he destroyed it all. What a lost opportunity.I guess I'm expecting more from people in their twenties, whether potheads or no, a serious situation is a serious situation, right?  These people act like thirteen year olds, like my nephew, just very unaware of consequences. It was infuriating to watch.As for the rest of the movie, the twists and turns, the brutality, eh.  It was okay.  I think Salma Hayek was good in her role, but I don't like the relationship that was developed between her character and O, it, too, was off and contrived. reviewText: To give Oliver Stone credit, he has contributed some the most powerful films in cinematic history. But less can be said for his most recent film SAVAGES. I will admit that this isn't the worst film I've ever seen. Hell, it's not even the worst Oliver Stone film I've ever seen. That said, the film lacks a lot of what makes an Oliver Stone film compelling and what makes an audience stand up with full attention. Based on a novel, that I haven't read, it tells the story of two pot dealers Ben and Chon, who live the high life in Laguna Beach with their shared girlfriend O. Yes, her name is O just like the magazine. With their business taking off they soon catch some unwanted attention from a mexican cartel who ultimately take O hostage until they get a slice of the boy's profit. Now the performances are nothing to be sneezed at, because after all these are some fine actors. Salma Hayek gives a great and very humanistic portrayal of the cartel queen Elena and Benicio Del Toro is at the top of his game. I will even go as far as to praise John Travolta's performance as the crooked DEA agent. The actors are not the problem here, it's the story. The film drags where it shouldn't, the storyline drifts from one characters problems to the next without any real detail, and the ending is something that is less to be desired. In fact, for those who have seen the film and will know what I'm talking about, it should of ended with the three main characters lying in the desert. I know that sounds grim but for a film like this it would of worked.Oliver Stone is a filmmaker who takes risks, and I admire that. But of course with risks comes consequences. And I think SAVAGES has suffered from that.
